title: 108_s1752
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act". The Arabia Mountain area contains natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources worthy of recognition and conservation. Managing these resources through partnerships between public and private entities is the best approach. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in Georgia protects various ecosystems and federally-protected plant species. Panola Mountain, a national natural landmark, is also located in the area. Panola Mountain, located in Panola Mountain State Conservation Park, is a rare granite outcrop. Miners Creek Preserve shows evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain display the history of granite mining. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation. Lithonia has 2 structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The goal is to preserve and promote natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other significant sites. Assistance is provided to develop and implement a management program to protect and interpret these resources within the heritage area. The Act defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State." The Act establishes the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area. The Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area is established in the State, consisting of certain parcels of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. The map depicting the boundaries is available for public inspection. The Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance is designated as the management entity for the heritage area. The management entity has authorities and duties outlined in the Act. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area has authorities to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers diverse interests within the area and gives priority to certain tasks. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area has the authority to prioritize actions from the management plan, assist in resource preservation, encourage land use policies, conduct quarterly public meetings, and submit an annual report to the Secretary. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income. They are also required to make all records available for audit and ensure receiving organizations do the same. Federal funds under this Act cannot be used to acquire real estate. Federal funds under this Act can be used to acquire real property or an interest in real property. The management entity is not restricted from using other Federal funds for authorized purposes. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a management plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept in the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study". The plan should consider State and local plans, involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include an inventory of resources in the heritage area. The management plan for the heritage area includes a list of significant properties to be preserved, an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation involving various entities. The management plan for the heritage area must include the protection of resources, identification of funding sources, and evaluation of the management entity. It should be submitted to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the enactment of the Act. Failure to submit the plan will result in a halt of additional funding under the Act. The management plan for the heritage area must be submitted to the Secretary within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Funding under the Act will be halted until the plan is submitted. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days, providing recommendations for revisions if needed. After the management plan for the heritage area is approved, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the plan to the Secretary for approval within 90 days. The management entity must submit recommendations for any revisions to the approved heritage area plan to the Secretary for approval within 90 days. No funds from this Act can be used to implement any proposed revisions until approved by the Secretary. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary may provide assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. SEC. 8. EFFECT ON CERTAIN AUTHORITY. The Act does not impose stricter regulations on occupational, safety, conservation, or environmental aspects in the heritage area than those applicable to the land before its establishment. It also does not authorize federal agencies to create more stringent regulations solely due to the heritage area's establishment. The Act does not change existing regulations on land use or grant zoning powers to the management entity. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is set at $10,000,000, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 50 percent. The Secretary's authority to grant assistance under the Act ends on September 30, 2016.
